Dear Mr. Medeiros:

This is in further response to your December 26, 2024, Freedom of Information Act
request, received by the Civil Rights Division, seeking access to records pertaining to:

1. OSC Case Records Complete files, internal and external communications,
investigations, and resolutions regarding: DI-25-000310; DI-25-000325; DI-25-
000379; DI-12192024714; DI-12112024134.

2. Interagency Correspondence Communications between OSC, FBI, DOJ, CMS,
HHS, and relevant state agencies regarding: Whistleblower disclosures and
investigations. Enforcement of ADA, Medicaid transparency, and constitutional
compliance. Allegations or investigations into fraud, retaliation, and procedural
violations.

3. FBI Involvement Documentation reflecting FBI’s role in addressing OSC-related
investigations, whistleblower protections, and Medicaid; compliance. Include:
Correspondence with OSC, DOJ, CMS and HHS regarding whistleblower
allegations. Investigative records and findings.

4. DOJ and HHS Oversight DOJ Civil Rights Division and HHS OCR records
related to: ADA compliance investigations. Complaints and procedural
documentation under OCR Transaction Number 01-25-592844. Federal and state
enforcement actions against systemic non-compliance.

5. CMS and Medicaid Audits All internal and external audits, investigations, and
compliance reviews associated with the Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI)
Waiver Program. Documents relating to whistleblower-reported fraud, misuse of
funds, and oversight deficiencies.
Freedom of Information/PA Unit –4CON
950 Pennsylvania Ave., NW
Washington, DC 20530

6. FOIA Compliance Records Metadata, processing logs, and communications
related to this FOIA request, including: Identified responsible officers and internal

procedural reviews.

After a thorough search, I have determined that the Civil Rights Division has no records
pertaining your request.

If you are not satisfied with the Civil Rights Division’s determination in response to this
request, you may administratively appeal by writing to the Director, Office of Information Policy
(OIP), United States Department of Justice, 441 G Street, NW, 6th Floor, Washington, D.C.
20530, or you may submit an appeal through OIP's FOIA STAR portal by creating an account on
the following website: https://www.justice.gov/oip/submit-and-track-request-or-appeal. Your
appeal must be postmarked or electronically transmitted within 90 days of the date of my
response to your request. If you submit your appeal by mail, both the letter and the envelope
should be clearly marked "Freedom of Information Act Appeal."
Additionally, you may contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at
the National Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIA mediation services
they offer. The contact information for OGIS is: Office of Government Information Services,
National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park,
Maryland 20740-6001; e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-
684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. Please reference the FOIA/PA No. above in any
correspondence with OGIS.
I hope the Civil Rights Division has been of some assistance to you in this matter.

Sincerely,

April N. Freeman
April Freeman, FOIA Liaison
Freedom of Information/Privacy Acts Unit
Civil Rights Division

We acknowledge your request and are committed to communicating with requesters. After an initial review when it was received, your request was placed in our “Simple” track for FOIA requests. (OSC categorizes its FOIA requests in three tracks, “simple,” “complex,” and “expedited.” We then generally process the requests in the order in which they were received within each category). Because your request is Simple and it has been a long time since you made the request, OSC would like to confirm that you are still seeking the records requested. If you find that you no longer need the requested records,please advise BY REPLY EMAIL stating that you longer wish to have your request processed. We will administratively close your request at that time. If you remain interested in the records, please advise BY REPLY EMAIL stating that you wish to have your request processed. You may wish to consider narrowing the scope of your request, which will allow us to provide a response more quickly. If you wish to speak with someone directly, you may contact the FOIA Public Liaison, at 202-804-7000. If we do not receive a response to this message within 30 working days, we will administratively close your request. Thank you for your attention to this matter. We look forward to hearing from you soon! Thank you,

Please note that although the Medicaid program is jointly funded by the federal government and the states, each individual state is responsible for administering the operations of their Medicaid program. CMS is not in possession of Medicaid claims records, and therefore we are unable to provide these state records. Therefore, after a careful search of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) files, i.e., a search reasonably calculated to locate records responsive to your request and employing reasonable standards, we were unable to locate any records responsive to your request.If you view our response as an adverse determination, you may appeal. To do so, you must put your appeal in writing and mail it within 30 days of the date of this letter to: The Principal Deputy Administrator, CMS, C5-16-03, 7500 Security Boulevard,Baltimore, Maryland 21244-1850. The challenges we face today demand more than acknowledgment—they require action, collaboration, and a unified commitment to solutions. Together, we must embrace transparency, accountability, and compassion as the
foundation of our efforts. By fostering open communication, prioritizing the needs of the most vulnerable, and holding systems accountable, we can rebuild trust and ensure equitable outcomes for all.

Solutions lie in unity—when state and federal leaders, advocates, and communities work hand in hand to uphold justice and fairness. Transparency through accessible Freedom of Information processes, adherence to legal
mandates, and robust oversight are the pillars that support meaningful change. Each of us has a role to play in creating a system that serves and protects.

Our collective mission is clear: to build bridges between agencies and communities, ensure the dignity of every individual, and honor the principles that guide us toward progress. Together, with determination and unity, we can
overcome systemic failures and pave the way for a brighter, more inclusive future.

Americans living with disabilities and their families are Americans—full citizens of this nation, protected by the same Constitution that guarantees the rights and freedoms of every individual. We are not separate, lesser, or forgotten. We are Americans with the same unalienable rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.

We stand firmly on the principles of equality, dignity, and justice. Our voices matter. Our contributions matter. And our rights—our Constitutional rights—must be respected, upheld, and protected without exception or delay.

We are Americans with rights. Period.

David Medeiros

https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Mercer County Jury Information
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern:
Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act I hereby request the following records:
The following materials regarding the compilation and composition of the state’s master jury list:

All current policies and procedures regarding how the current master jury list was compiled and how often master jury lists are reviewed and updated. Please name all source lists (driver’s license records, voter registration lists, etc) that were utilized in creating the current master jury list.

All reports, databases, spreadsheets, or equivalent materials regarding the composition of the current master jury list. Please include the total number of individuals on the current master jury list and all relevant demographic data, including but not limited to the race, age and gender of individuals that comprise the current master jury list.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jenny Wadhwa

title: White House Hanukkah Party - Marine Band

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: White House Hanukkah Party - Marine Band
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. The after action report, the plan of the day, and the trip itinerary for the US Marine Band’s December 16, 2024 White House performances.
2. Correspondence between any employee, official, or officer of the US Marine Band and the White House  concerning the band’s December 16, 2024 performance.
3. Copies of any musical arrangements, or recordings created in preparation or for the US Marine Corps Band's December 16, 2024 White House performance.

Please limit your search to the period between November 1, 2024 - December 17, 2024.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. I believe that I should be categorized as an “Other Requester,” requiring me to pay for the Search and Duplication, excluding the cost of the first 2 hours of search and 100 pages. I expect that this request will be within that range.

In the unlikely event that the request exceeds that limit, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Russel Neiss

communications.subject: Your FOIA Request 2025-USMCFOIA-001448
communications.communication:
Good Morning Mr. Neiss, 

This is to acknowledge the receipt of your request and to let you know that I am the analyst assigned for processing. 

Please be aware that, whenever a FOIA requester has not received a determination within 20 working days from the date a request is perfected, they are entitled to challenge the delay.  To do this, you may submit an appeal within the SecureRelease online portal (www.securerelease.us) or by writing to the Department of the Navy, Office of the Judge Advocate General (Code 14), 1322 Patterson Ave SE, Suite 3000, Washington Navy Yard, DC 20374-5066.  If you prefer, you can also submit an appeal via e-mail to Lieutenant Commander Greggary Lines, USN, at greggary.e.lines.mil@us.navy.mil and/or Ms. Wendy Winston at 202-685-5446 or wendy.a.winston.civ@us.navy.mil.  Your appeal, if any, should include a statement indicating why you believe it should be granted.  It must be postmarked or timestamped within 90 calendar days from the date of this letter. 

Requesters also have the right to seek assistance and/or dispute resolution services from the Department of the Navy FOIA Public Liaison, Mr. Christopher Julka, at Christopher.a.julka@navy.mil or (703) 697-0031, and may also contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) for assistance and/or dispute resolution at ogis@nara.gov or (877) 684-6448. 

Thank you for your patience as we work to complete the processing of your request. 

Sincerely, 
Tara M. Walters

communications.subject: Ref: F-2023-05799, Freedom of Information Act Acknowledgement
communications.communication: **THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.** Mr.AFL: This email acknowledges receipt of your March 1, 2023, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552) request received by the U.S. Department of State, Office ofInformation Programs and Services on March 2, 2023, regarding"all emails to or from George Noll regarding the repatriation of the Assyrian spoon to the Palestinian Authority. The time period for this request is from November 1, 2022, to the date of processing.". Unless you advise otherwise, we will treat as non-responsive any compilations of publicly available news reports and any publicly available documents not created by the U.S. government, such as mass-distribution emails from news media.  This Office assigned your request the subject reference number and placed it in the complex processing track where it will beprocessed as quickly as possible.  See 22 CFR § 171.11(h). This Office willnot be able to respond within the 20 days provided by the statute due to“unusual circumstances.” See 5 U.S.C. §552(a)(6)(B)(i)-(iii). In this instance,the unusual circumstances include the need to search for and collect requestedrecords from other Department offices or Foreign Service posts. If you have any questions regarding yourrequest , would like to narrow the scope or arrange analternative time frame to speed its processing, or would like an estimated dateof completion, please contact our FOIA Requester Service Center or our FOIAPublic Liaison by email at FOIAstatus@state.gov or telephone at202-261-8484.  Additionally, youmay contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at theNational Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIAmediation services they offer. Thecontact information for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government InformationServices, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS,College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, email at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. **THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.**

communications.subject: RE: FOIA Request F-2023-05799- More information is needed
communications.communication:
Dear AFL, This email correspondence pertains to your March 1, 2023,Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. §552) request received March 2,2023, by the U.S. Department of State, Office of Information Programs andServices. You are seeking a copy of "allemails to or from George Noll regarding the repatriation of the Assyrian spoonto the Palestinian Authority. The time period for this request is from November1, 2022, to the date of processing.". To help ensure a faster response, more information is needed from youabout what you are seeking. If possible, please provide additionalsubject matter search terms to assist in the search for the records sought. You may reply by contacting FOIArequest@state.gov or by mailing, the Office ofInformation Programs and Services, U.S. Department of State, 2201 C Street, NW,Room B266, Washington, D.C. 20520; or facsimile at 202-485-1718. Please email us to help ensure a faster response. If you do not replyby May 31, 2023, then we will proceed with the request without this clarification. Regards M. Trask 
RequesterCommunications Branch 
Requester Liaison Division

communications.communication:
Thanks so much for your response.
I know that many counties and cities in California have  searchable websites for all contracts they engage in. For example,  San Diego County has this link  https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/purchasing/documentum-contract-search.html
Might  Orange County have a website link like that?
If not, please refer to my original request which is to your department, the Orange County Sheriff's Office for  all grants, contracts, reports including financial, MOUs, and all communications including emails with the words "prostitution", "sex trafficking", "human trafficking" for the years 2000 through 2026.
Happy Holidays
Maxine Doogan
415-265-3302

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Yonkers PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Yonkers Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Gelardi

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Yonkers PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
Dear Chris Gelardi:



This will acknowledge receipt of your request for records under the Freedom of Information Law received by the Division of Criminal Justice Services on March 22, 2024. The request was for "All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Yonkers Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present."



Your request has been forwarded to the appropriate program area(s) to identify documents that are responsive to your request and which may be made available pursuant to all applicable provisions of the Freedom of Information Law.



A determination as to whether your request is granted or denied will be reached in approximately 20 business days or we will notify you in writing if the responsible program area(s) should require additional time to locate, assemble and review documents that may be responsive to your request.



Please note that, pursuant to Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, a charge may be applied to your request, including the actual cost of the medium used to respond to your Freedom of Information Law request and/or other related costs.  When responsive records have been identified, you will be informed of any cost and how payment should be made.







Very truly yours,


Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

Pursuant to POL §89(4)(a), you may appeal this determination within 30 days to the Counsel, Division of Criminal Justice Services, 80 South Swan St., Albany, NY 12210 or by email at foil@dcjs.ny.gov<mailto:foil@dcjs.ny.gov>.

Very truly yours,

Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Agency Roster
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current annual salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

Dear Chris Gelardi:

This is in response to your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request for "All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Mount Vernon Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present."

Please find links to 2 PDF documents that are responsive to your request. Please note that pursuant to Sections 87(2)(b) and 87(2)(e)(iv) of the Public Officers Law (POL), certain portions have been redacted for personal privacy and to not reveal criminal investigative techniques or procedures.

Pursuant to POL §89(4)(a), you may appeal this determination within 30 days to the Counsel, Division of Criminal Justice Services, 80 South Swan St., Albany, NY 12210 or by email at foil@dcjs.ny.gov<mailto:foil@dcjs.ny.gov>.

Very truly yours,

Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Buffalo PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Buffalo Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Gelardi

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Buffalo PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
Dear Chris Gelardi:



This will acknowledge receipt of your request for records under the Freedom of Information Law received by the Division of Criminal Justice Services on March 22, 2024. The request was for "All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Buffalo Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present."



Your request has been forwarded to the appropriate program area(s) to identify documents that are responsive to your request and which may be made available pursuant to all applicable provisions of the Freedom of Information Law.



A determination as to whether your request is granted or denied will be reached in approximately 20 business days or we will notify you in writing if the responsible program area(s) should require additional time to locate, assemble and review documents that may be responsive to your request.



Please note that, pursuant to Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, a charge may be applied to your request, including the actual cost of the medium used to respond to your Freedom of Information Law request and/or other related costs.  When responsive records have been identified, you will be informed of any cost and how payment should be made.







Very truly yours,


Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

title: Pennsylvania Executive Order on "Scandalous or Disagraceful Conduct" (Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board)

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Pennsylvania Executive Order on "Scandalous or Disagraceful Conduct" (Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

For purposes of this request, "SCANDALOUS OR DISGRACEFUL CONDUCT POLICY" means any of: (a) Executive Order No. 1980-18 Amended, dated May 6, 2024, 54 Pa.B. 3018; (b) 4 Pa. Code §  7.158.1 ("Personal conduct," providing that "No employee, appointee or official of the Executive Branch of the Commonwealth may engage in scandalous or disgraceful conduct, or any other behavior, on or off duty, which may bring the service of the Commonwealth into disrepute") or (c) any policy, guidance, regulation, or other prohibition against "scandalous or disgraceful conduct, or any other behavior, on or off duty, which may bring the service of the Commonwealth into disrepute."

1. Any records reflecting a complaint, charge, or disciplinary action concerning any violation (or alleged violation) of a SCANDALOUS OR DISGRACEFUL CONDUCT POLICY.

2. Any records reflecting any warning issued to any employee concerning the SCANDALOUS OR DISGRACEFUL CONDUCT POLICY.

3. Any policy, guidance, regulation, or handbook concerning the SCANDALOUS OR DISGRACEFUL CONDUCT POLICY.

This request is limited to records generated on or after May 5, 2024.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

communications.subject: RE: [External] Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Pennsylvania Executive Order on "Scandalous or Disagraceful Conduct" (Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board)
communications.communication:
Dear Requester,

Please be advised that your request for records made pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right-To-Know Law ("RTKL") [65 P.S. §§ 67.101, et seq.] was logged as having been received by the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board's ("PLCB") Agency Open Records Office on January 23, 2025.

The PLCB has now started the process of searching for and reviewing records that may potentially be responsive to your request.

Under the RTKL, the PLCB has five business days from the above date (or until January 30, 2025) to provide you with either of the following: a final written response to your request or written notice that the PLCB is exercising its right, pursuant to section 902(b) of the RTKL [65 P.S. § 67.902(b)], to take an extension of up to an additional thirty calendar days to provide a final written response to your request along with any responsive records deemed to be subject to "public disclosure."
Best regards,
PLCB Agency Open Records Office

files.title: ~WRD0001
files.source: Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board, Pennsylvania

communications.subject: RTKL 25-14 Final Response
communications.communication:
Dear Requester,

Please find attached the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board's ("PLCB") final response to your written request for records made pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right-To-Know Law [65 P.S. §§ 67.101, et seq.] along with the records that the PLCB has determined to be responsive to your request and subject to "public disclosure."  A copy of your request is also attached herewith for your convenience.

Should you have any questions regarding this matter, please feel free to contact the PLCB's Agency Open Records Office unless otherwise instructed in the attached letter.
Best regards,

PLCB Agency Open Records Office

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Miami-Dade police disciplinary files
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

- Any and all lists, spreadsheets or other organized datasets that detail potential or substantiated allegations of misconduct and/or impeached or impeachable testimony, created under Brady v. Maryland and/or Giglio v. United States.
- Any and all records regarding substantiated allegations of misconduct or violations of internal department policy or criminal law by specific law enforcement officers.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Dillon Bergin

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Miami-Dade police disciplinary files
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

As to you first request: While we maintain a Brady list, our list consists of pending investigations known to the officers as well as the pending charges against the officers, which are considered Brady by law.  See attached.
As to your second request: We do not track such information, as such we have no responsive public records.
Lastly, as an aside, unlike other jurisdictions, in Florida pursuant to Chapter 119, F.S., closed police disciplinary investigative files are a matter of public record and are available from individual employing police agencies.

title: FOIA Request for Case-Related Materials - cassandritz blanc (Broward County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: FOIA Request for Case-Related Materials - cassandritz blanc (Broward County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am writing to formally request access to public records under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). Specifically, I am requesting any and all records and materials related to the case of

Suspect Name: cassandritz blanc
Description/Headline: Broward man accused of murdering pregnant wife and her father gets 3 life sentences
Link of the Article: https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/broward-man-accused-of-murdering-pregnant-wife-and-her-father-gets-3-life-sentences/3106141/
State: California 
Law Enforcement: Broward County

included but not limited to the following:
Documents:
Incident reports
Investigation reports
Officer statements
Witness statements
Any other relevant case files

Footage:
Body camera footage from officers on the scene
Dash camera footage
Police surveillance camera footage
Private/public surveillance footage from nearby locations
Any footage collected as evidence or during the investigation

Audio:
911 calls
Police radio communications
Any other audio recordings related to the case
Visual Media:
Crime scene photographs
Surveillance stills
Photographs taken during the investigation

Court Records:
Transcripts from court hearings or proceedings
Any video/audio footage from court hearings
Court orders or any other court-related documents

Please include any and all materials, regardless of format (digital or physical), including those not listed above that are related to the case in question.
Additionally, if this request has been sent to the wrong department or agency, I would appreciate it if you could provide guidance or contact information for the correct department or agency that handles such requests.

If any part of the request is denied or redacted, please provide a detailed explanation of the specific legal exemption that applies.
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response within the period mandated by FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

david yupa

communications.subject: [Records Center] Welcome to the Records Center!
communications.communication:
Dear david yupa, 
 
Thank you for registering with the Broward County Sheriff Public Records Center. If you have never used this system, your account has been created by a staff person at Broward County Sheriff's Office. 
 
Once your email address has been verified, you can log in to the Public Records Center to update any contact or password information and to track the progress of your request. 
 
 Login: 179589-81383674@requests.muckrock.com 
 
To verify your email address, the following activation link to set a password will be active for 24 hours. 
 Activate Online Account 
 
If the activation link expires, you will need to request a password by clicking the link below. This will allow you to access your request, manage account information, and retrieve responsive records. 
 
 Request a Password (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXcG3Wr1V145KpTsNEi9u7JfrXFsT6tourVE6ng05QNQK4uy3nDLpKgYAvkV9FO7eZXyWQHxUzJMyiZfdhujTm38-3DOUjm_7UcghLKjJN-2Fsa93Tz1wOzq4nHwcgN-2FtlDBLsaB5H23hnARuNFzjVHnGPLLhB4LUDEym3uH-2Bq0ZBFuLZ9CN4Xs4UY-2Fw1DE7bLPUju0Y-2Fy4Em80PXd-2FcAoN4NC3sTdeCVIZDFIh9oiZp4EQQLgNdF52csq1-2B-2FzAsX0iLUGQITr6gczn9BK8sySN-2FsSvoBML3SVTePtVvvkCAASHCPLmofLtPjn0YffpvM9ISgFNKlrqok-3D) 
 PLEASE NOTE: All requests are completed in the order they are received. Please understand some requests may take more than a week to fulfill. If a request takes a large amount of time to complete, then an estimate will be sent to you and a deposit or full payment may be required. When an invoice is sent to you for payment, payment must be received immediately.  If payment is not received in an allotted amount of time we will freeze all future requests until all unpaid invoices are paid in full and up to date. (refer to FSS: 119.07 (4)(d). If a request is no longer needed please contact our office immediately.  If the request is fulfilled before we are notified that the documents are no longer necessary, then payment must still be made for our time and efforts. If you plan to pick up your request please contact us in advance. 
 
Thank you, 
 Broward County Sheriff's Office This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY

communications.subject: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: ICE requests-NM (Deming Public Schools)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1) By school, the number of student incident reports forwarded or otherwise provided to the New Mexico All Source Intelligence Center and/or Immigration and Customs Enforcement between September 1, 2020 and present; 

1a) and any such reports with student names redacted.

2) All documents indicating, reflecting or referencing any policies, processes, practices, guidance, directives, memoranda and/or recommendations regarding your school district generating, sending and/or transmitting school district documents to any divisions, employees, and/or agents of New Mexico All Source Intelligence Center and/or Immigration and Customs Enforcement between September 1, 2020 and present.

3) all documents received from and/or generated by your school district and sent to, transmitted to, or otherwise made available or accessible to the New Mexico All Source Intelligence Center  and/or Immigration and Customs Enforcement and/or any of their employees or agents between Sept 1 2020 and the present;

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marina Villeneuve

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: "St. Louis Cardinals" Specialized License Plate Sales
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Request for comprehensive sales data regarding the "St. Louis Cardinals" commemorative vehicle license plates, as authorized under Statute 301.472. The desired documentation should provide a detailed breakdown of plate issuance volumes, categorized chronologically by year and, if available, by month and year, tracking the sales history since this plate design's introduction.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Eisen

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Dana George Mead
communications.communication:
Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 134 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 523 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,335 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,875 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS) FBI-Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive, Winchester, VA 22602-4843
Direct: (540) 868-4593
Fax: (540) 868-4391
Questions E-mail: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #DOJ-AP-2019-002025
communications.communication:
Appeals are handled by the Office of Information Policy (OIP), U.S. Department of Justice, not the FBI.  Once OIP renders a decision regarding your appeal, the FBI will be notified of the decision.
For all appeals or appeal status updates please contact OIP (you must clearly cite your FOIPA number in any correspondence to OIP to have your request properly identified).
You can track the status of your appeal at https://www.justice.gov/oip/submit-and-track-request-or-appeal or call 202-514-3642.

When writing to OIP please use the following address:
Director
Freedom of Information Appeal
Office of Information Policy (OIP)
U.S. Department of Justice
1425 New York Avenue, NW, Suite 11050
Washington D.C. 20530-001

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer

title: William J. Clinton Presidential Library: WHTV Tapes of November 6th 1994 Speech at the Pike Place Market in Seattle, Washington

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: William J. Clinton Presidential Library: WHTV Tapes of November 6th 1994 Speech at the Pike Place Market in Seattle, Washington
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

White House Communications Agency video footage (WHTV content) filmed during Presidential Clinton's November 6th 1994 speech at Seattle's Pike Place Market. This is a request to review all footage from the speech at the Pike Place Market, including outtakes and rushes and any footage of the arrival or departure. I am unable to find any audio or video of this event online. It would be greatly appreciated if, following review, any released video could be uploaded to the @clintonlibrary42 YouTube page. 

Here's a link to a transcript of the remarks: https://clintonwhitehouse6.archives.gov/1994/11/1994-11-06-president-remarks-at-washington-state-rally.html 

Thank you for your commitment to transparency, and I look forward to working with you all on this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

communications.subject: Re: Freedom of Information Act Request: William J. Clinton Presidential Library: WHTV Tapes of November 6th 1994 Speech at the Pike Place Market in Seattle, Washington
communications.communication:
Good afternoon.

For this event shot by the WHTV Unit you do not need to file a FOIA request
to review the material. Pre request, the event has been placed onto the
ClintonLibrary42 YouTube channel. The event has been placed at the
following link; [ President Clinton at Rally in Seattle, WA (1994) - YouTube
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fj80HXnGg-8> ]. It may not immediately be
available for viewing, and if that is the case please allow a little bit of
time for it to be encoded for YouTube playback.

The event was adjusted to match the title assigned by the Federal Register
and as printed by the Government Printing Office. The original title on the
archived WhiteHouse.gov webpage was a press office assigned title prior to
the event entering the Federal Register.

This event consisted of two main taps and a roving camera. All three of the
clips were included which encompasses the entirety of your request. There
was no further material from the Pike Place Market event.

There was a transition point in the footage of MT02990 to MT02991 at
approximately 29:11 in the footage. As the material was originally shot on
30 minute Betacam format there was a practical limitation of having two
cameras run side-by-side to ensure all of the President's remarks were
captured for record. Where appropriate we try to splice these transition
points together so they are seamless and to align better with what
researchers expect video to look like. I believe we got pretty close there
with the seam point. The first tape MT02990 was also observed to have high
incoming audio levels from the Mult. It was adjusted to match MT02991's
level which is more proper for the event's setting and not as distorted.

Let us know if you have any immediate questions.

- Herbert

Herbert Ragan
*Audio/Visual Archivist / **National Archives and Records
Administration / **William
J. Clinton Presidential Library*


*1200 President Clinton Ave., Little Rock, AR  72201Ph (direct): (501)
244-2852Herbert.Ragan@nara.gov <Herbert.Ragan@nara.gov>*

<https://www.facebook.com/WJCLibrary/> | [image:
https://www.youtube.com/user/clintonlibrary42]
<https://www.youtube.com/user/clintonlibrary42> | [image:
https://twitter.com/WJCLibrary] <https://twitter.com/WJCLibrary> | [image:
https://www.instagram.com/wjclibrary42/]
<https://www.instagram.com/wjclibrary42/>

*The contents of this message may represent personal opinions and/or
analysis and do not necessarily reflect any position of the U.S. Government
or the National Archives and Records Administration.  **If you have
received this message in error, please dispose of the message immediately.*

Hello. 

I am following up as it has been well over 7 business days since the form was returned to you as requested. Per the guidelines :

If records are readily available, they should be provided promptly. However, if it is not practicable for the records to be made promptly available, the records custodian is required to take one of the following actions within seven (7) business days: make the records available to the requestor; deny the request in writing, providing the basis of the denial; or provide the requestor a written explanation of the time reasonably necessary to produce the records.  Tenn. Code Ann. § 10-7-503(1)(2)(B).

Please respond appropriately at your earliest convenience.

title: Request to NASA for all 2024 movie collaborations

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to NASA for all 2024 movie collaborations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of all the films that NASA has participated in the production of, in any capacity whatsoever, for the year 2024. Any and all such lists, full or partial, would be appreciated and may include, but are not limited to, entertainment liaison (ELO) reports, production assistance agreements, or similar internal documents. I request that you search for these documents in any location where they might be located, including but not limited to the entertainment liaison offices, public affairs offices, and communications HQ.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Appendix "C" of the US Navy Court of Inquiry Report into USS Liberty Attack

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Appendix "C" of the US Navy Court of Inquiry Report into USS Liberty Attack
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am a survivor of th eJune 8, 1967, Israeli attack on the USS Liberty and serve my shipmates as Historian of the USS Liberty Veterans Association.

Page 21 of the summarization included in the US Navy Court of Inquiry Report prepared following the US Navy Court of Inquiry into the June 8, 1967, Israeli Defense Force attack on the USS Liberty refers to “Appendix C” being attached to the summarization, which contains the death certificates of the 34 USS Liberty crewmen killed during the IDF attack on our ship.

Appendix C does not appear in any of the versions of the Court of Inquiry Report I have.

I request that you release to me a copy of Appendix C referenced on page 21 of 23 of the summarization of the US Navy Court of Inquiry Report.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joe Meadors

communications.subject: Fwd: [25-20011] Freedom of Information Act Request - Joe Meadors
communications.communication:
Dear Joe Meadors,

This is in response to your Freedom of Information Act request dated
January 12, 2025 for records relating to death certificates for individuals
that were killed in action on the USS Liberty on the approximate dates of
June 1967. Your request was received in this office, A2 Textual Reference,
on the date of January 16, 2024 and assigned FOIA case number 25-20011.


We have conducted a records review for Appendix C for the Court of Inquiry
for the USS Liberty in relation to the attack on the USS Liberty that
occurred on June 8, 1967. During our records review we reviewed Record
Group 125: Records of the U.S. Navy Judge Advocate General. Unfortunately,
we were unable to locate a copy of this record. These records may remain
with the U.S. Navy's Judge advocate general. We did locate a scanned copy
of this document online. This copy is held on the website The Liberty
Incident (http://www.thelibertyincident.com/docs/courtofinquiry.pdf) Please
note that the identified website is not an official source of U.S.
Government records, however, we have included the link for reference and
note that Appendix C can be located on page 47 of that document.
Additionally, we have attached a copy of Appendix C as it appears in that
document. Appendix C appears to be a name list of those killed in action.
We recommend contacting the website www.thelibertyincident.com to determine
the origin of the source for the copy of the Court of Inquiry they retain
on their website. They may be able to identify the Agency or Office within
the U.S. Navy that currently holds the original records and they may be
able to determine if copies of the Death Certificates were included with
the original Court of Inquiry.


During our records review we did locate files that may be relevant to your
research. These records were located in the following:


Record Group 24: Records of the U.S. Navy Bureau of Personnel

Series Title: Miscellaneous Casualty Records, 1941-1971

Box Numbers: 9 & 10

File Title: USS Liberty, 8 June 1967, 34 Crewmembers Dead (8 June 1967-9
February 1970)

File Title: USS Liberty – Incoming Messages & Notifications – MIA & Dead,
1967 (1 of 2) (June 1967)
File Title: USS Liberty – Incoming Messages & Notifications – MIA & Dead,
1967 (2 of 2) (June 1967)
File Title: USS Liberty – Incoming Messages & Notifications – Injured, 1967
(10 June-1 July 1967)

The above materials are already open for public viewing in our research
room at the National Archives in College Park, MD, located at 8601 Adelphi
Road, College Park, MD. We are staffed to assist researchers with their
work by providing onsite reference services. Since there are no access
restrictions on these documents, there is no need to file a Freedom of
Information Act request with the National Archives.


We will be happy to make the records and their finding aids available to
you or your representative in the Textual Research Room (Room 2000) here at
the National Archives at College Park, Maryland. Please visit our website
for information about visiting the National Archives in College Park, MD
<https://www.archives.gov/college-park>, including how to schedule a
research visit. If you are unable to visit our research reading rooms you
may consider hiring a private researcher to conduct research on your
behalf. The scope of your research, combined with our staffing limitations
may make this the most efficient way to provide you with professional
research services. A list of private researchers who are familiar with
National Archives facilities is available on our Independent Researchers
Available for Hire <https://www.archives.gov/research/hire-help> webpage.


This concludes the processing of your request. We do not consider this a
denial of your FOIA request. If you are not satisfied with our action on
this request, your options for appeal and dispute resolution are attached.


If you have a follow up request please send your request to
archives2reference@nara.gov. We hope you find this information useful in
conducting your research.


Sincerely,


JACOB A. HAYWOOD

Textual Reference Archives II Branch (RR2RR)

National Archives at College Park, MD

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Marilyn Monroe
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records, specifically those unreleased, mentioning or describing Marilyn Monroe (born: June 1, 1926; died: August 4, 1962). Her death was widely covered in the media.

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. Please search HQ records as well as ALL field offices and resident agencies.

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. I have previously written about the government and its activities, and am currently a reporter of The Boston Globe.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexa Gagosz

communications.subject: FOIA Request #1412777-000
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Mr. Galante,

Reference is made to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request #1412777-000 for FBI records concerning File 062-HQ-62736, Postal Censorship.  The FBI has located approximately 83,000 pages that are potentially responsive to your request.  Once requests go over a certain size, usually in the 50-100 page range, they become increasingly complex, greatly slowing down the time required for processing.  Generally the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.  Given our current workload and staffing levels, it may be a very long time before you would begin to receive material from this request.

Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 134 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 523 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,335 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,875 days for processing.  

Your request is currently in the complex request large processing track, and the estimated date of completion for your request is June 2025.  If your request is considered a complex track, considering reducing the scope of your request may accelerate the process as it could potentially place your request in a quicker processing track.  This may also reduce any search and duplication costs, if applicable, and allow for a more timely receipt of your information.  If you wish to discuss reducing the scope of your request, please respond to this email.  We appreciate your patience and hope to hear from you soon.

Sincerely,

Negotiation Team
FOIA Support Unit
Information Management Division
Federal Bureau of Investigation
540-868-4894
Status check?  Please contact Public Information Officer at foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

I'm following up to the email sent out last week to you with regards to your FOIA # 1412777-000 on File 062-HQ-62736.  The previous email goes into more detail for our contact with you.  If you are interested in narrowing the scope of your request, please respond either by email or phone. 

Thank you for your time and attention to this inquiry.

Sincerely,

communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 138 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 571 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,289 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,649 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS) FBI-Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive, Winchester, VA 22602-4843
Direct: (540) 868-4593
Fax: (540) 868-4391
Questions E-mail: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 138 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 571 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,289 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,649 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
F: (540) 868-4391
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1412777-000
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Mr. Galante,

We wanted to reach out to you once again to see if you might be possibly interested in narrowing the scope of your request to possibly receive a release sooner. At 3703 potentially responsive pages, your request is currently in the large track. Requests in this track are taking approximately 66 months to process. By contrast, small track requests of up to 50 pages currently average approximately 5 months, and medium track requests of between 51-950 pages are currently averaging approximately 31 months.

Please let us know if you would be interested in possibly reducing the scope of your request.

Best regards,

Negotiation Team
Federal Bureau of Investigation
Fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov<mailto:Fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov>

Status Checks: https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps | foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>
For additional information, please visit the www.fbi.gov/foia<http://www.fbi.gov/foia> website.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1412777-000
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This is an appeal of FOIA request 1412777-000. I am appealing all applied exemptions in the records provided, particularly the application of b7e to records that are, at the time of my receiving them, eighty-three years old. The Bureau has previously disclosed law enforcement and intelligence techniques of this era, to include the interception of privileged diplomatic communications and collaboration with allied foreign intelligence services, methods that at the time would be highly damaging if disclosed but currently hold no value by remaining secret. The exemptions as applied in this release strain credulity and are prima facie absurd. I appreciate your anticipated cooperation in this matter.

Sincerely,
Paul Galante

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1412777-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request

If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-0] please enter [1195846-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-1] please enter [1195846-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000
Case Type:
FOIPA
Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)

The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.

You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.


Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Our complex requests are further divided into small (51-250 pages), medium (251-500 pages), large (501-4,999), and extra-large (over 5,000 pages) sub-tracks.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing. Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.
Currently, simple track cases average approximately 230 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Complex requests in the small processing track are currently averaging 1,085 days from the date of receipt for processing, those in the medium processing track are currently averaging 1,310 days, those in the large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,010 days, and those in the extra-large track are averaging 2,370 days  .


Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

title: All communications with Schilling Kingsbury Erin

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: All communications with Schilling Kingsbury Erin
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

ALL communications between jwilson@cityofberkeley.info and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between kfutch@cityofberkeley.info and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between JLouis@cityofberkeley.info and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between flandrum@cityofberkeley.info and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between jwilson@berkeleyca.gov and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between kfutch@berkeleyca.gov and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between JLouis@berkeleyca.gov and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between flandrum@berkeleyca.gov and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between jwilson@ci.berkeley.ca.us and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between kfutch@ci.berkeley.ca.us and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between JLouis@ci.berkeley.ca.us and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between flandrum@ci.berkeley.ca.us and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between flandrum@cityofberkeley.info and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between agreenwood@berkeleyca.gov and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between agreenwood@ci.berkeley.ca.us and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between lgoree@ymcaeastbay.org and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between lgoree@ymcaeastbay.org and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between KCatlos@kaufmandolowich.com and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between sdorsey@ymcaeastbay.org and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between kmaltais@ymcaeastbay.org and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between racosta@ymcaeastbay.org and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between hrhow@ymcaeastbay.org and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

ALL communications between fgallati@ymcaeastbay.org and erin.kingsbury@acgov.org

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Requester

communications.subject: Your CPRA request dated August 20, 2024 (Index 3675)
communications.communication:
Good morning,

We are in receipt of your request. To move forward with the email search, please provide a specific date range.

Also, Erin Kingsbury likely engaged with the Berkeley Police Department regarding numerous topics. Kindly limit your request by topic so that we do not spend resources reviewing documents that are not of interest.

Respectfully,




 [cid:1cf895db-ef62-49bb-ba1e-fb2f13593ee6]

Custodian of Records Unit/cmh

1225 Fallon St. #900, Oakland, CA 94612

o. 510-272-6222 • f. 510-271-5157



www.alcoda.org<http://www.alcoda.org/>

_____________________________________________________

CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: This message contains information which may be confidential and privileged. Unless you are the addressee, you may not use, copy, or disclose to anyone the message or any information contained in the message. If you have received this message in error, please advise the sender by reply e-mail, and delete the message. Thank you, the Alameda County District Attorney's Office.

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: All communications with Schilling Kingsbury Erin
communications.communication:
I would like all emails for all time periods.

I would like immediately emails relating to Hispanic defendants.

communications.subject: Re: California Public Records Act Request: All communications with Schilling Kingsbury Erin
communications.communication:
Good morning,

Thank you for your email. We cannot limit emails relating to Hispanic defendants as we have no way of knowing that a case involves a Hispanic defendant.  We can limit the inquiry to discussions of cases; however, there will likely be many exemptions.

The request is overbroad. Please focus your request by topic and provide a start date for the search.

We will wait to hear back from you.

Respectfully,
